options: virtual seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: knowledge on different building materials, methods of building applicable to both architect use and general model-making.

Hands-on introduction to constructing with paper, wood, concrete, masonry
Understanding of the physical and industrial processes underlying constructing with basic materials
How to interpret architecture from a materials-standpoint
different materials (wood, glass, steel, concrete, etc.) that are involved in architecture. How do architects plan, design, and build things from scratch.
Hands on work with various materials.

I developed knowledge about common building materials such as concrete, brick, and wood, and I developed skills to build using these materials. The one main insight I got out of this amazing class is: you can build anything you want, no matter how difficult it may seem. I also gained confidence and reinvigorated my creative side through this course, which I have been missing for a long time.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: 
very low-pressure environment allows for students to learn in their own right and really find the course material fascinating; Tim's knowledge and personal experience with materials in architecture from literal atoms to historical movements; allows students to guide their own learning and explore independently what they want to do for midterm and final precedent study

Weaknesses:
covid restrictions put a dampener on our introduction to welding, glass, bamboo; an otherwise noble effort to free students of any requirements/biases on what to do for their midterm and final projects led to an unnecessary and frustrating lack of communication, logistics, and financial support in buying materials

Strength: great professor and very nice TA; the in-person labs were very fun and it was especially exciting because we actually build things in person; 

Weakness: Could be better during a non-Covid time; the final project (which constitutes the majority of our grade) had very little guidance (which can be good or bad) but for me it was a bit stressful because I wanted a more clear direction.

Strengths of this course was the hands-on approach to learning about building materials in architecture. The in-person labs were successfully done and were both fun and educational. The only weakness in this course was the ambiguous precedent study, but this was intentionally vague in order for the most creative approaches to flourish, which I think was accomplished. I wish we were able to do welding, but according to COVID-19 safety guidelines and EHS guidelines, we were unable to do such.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
morning live lecture before the lab was very helpful context to what we would really be doing in the lab to follow

actual clearance to carry out the labs in-person would have allowed us a better understanding of the materials we weren't introduced to + better support for the final precedent studies
Virtual lectures were fine, and in-person labs were executed well in accordance with COVID-19 restrictions.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes; this class is genuinely very fun and teaches skills that are applicable across disciplines.

no one should go through Yale without exploring courses that put voluntary learning and exploration into what really fascinates you ahead of coursework and grades and studying. they are rare and this course is one of them. nevertheless, if you are the kind of student that can handle last-minute changes and being comfortable not knowing what exactly is expected, this course is your style. for those who are more by-the-syllabus and want to plan out a concrete idea of your work ahead of time, you may find the style of the course more of a struggle

Yes! Take this course especially if you are looking for a 5th class. It is fun, unique, and will give you a chance to learn about something completely different from your major requirement. The COVID edition in-person lab was still very fun but I wish I could have done some labs that got cancelled due to COVID guidelines. The Prof and the TA are both very nice and understanding. Prof Newton definitely cares about your well being and makes sure that this class would not give extra stress for you.
Yes! It's a fun hands-on course where you actually get to use and try what you learn in lectures.
Yes! It's a great 5th class to balance out a heavy workload. Very fun and engaging.

I would HIGHLY recommend this course to another student, even if you're like me and not an architecture major. This is one of the few classes that is actually hands-on, and you get to BUILD things! It provided me with a new confidence in building things, and reinvigorated my creative side. I cannot recommend this course enough to every student (but smaller classes definitely benefit the best).
